unless otherwise noted, all figures in this emodule are from gray’s anatomy for students, 3e, by drake , vogl and mitchell, © 2015 by elsevier. this is a recommended resource. click to begin click to begin click to begin emodule tutorial emodule tutorial emodule tutorial no, not that drake. even his talents have limits.

to complete each section, use the next button at the bottom of the pages or press the right arrow key to move forward one page at a time. use the menu, available by clicking “menu” at the top, to navigate to specific slides. use search to quickly find instances of relevant terms. use the previous button at the bottom of the pages or press the left arrow key to move back one page at a time. previous next using the emodule case 1 introduction approach diagnosis use this emodule before labs to prepare for them, during labs to guide your studies, and after labs as a review tool.

previous start conventions used in the emodule with age, wear and tear, info information that has implications for health and disease is introduced on a blue bar and continued below the bar: and how the superior and inferior articular facets of adjacent vertebrae articulate with one another. note how they fit together, tas k tasks, introduced on a pink bar and continued below the bar in bold, are actions that you should take to help you understand the content: an intervertebral disc can herniate, such that the nucleus pulposus…. the film button appears on the bottom bar of slides where a video accompanies tasks or explanations. the photo button appears at the bottom of slides where a photo accompanies tasks. some words are followed by an icon ; click the icon to jump to related information. click the icon to close it. some words are followed by an icon ; click the icon to see a definition. words / phrases in purple denote concepts with which you should become familiar. the slide talk icon appears on the top bar of slides containing a recording of me explaining concepts. info this is where i will share my thoughts with you %name%

lab instructions previous this content will be tested on the ent week mastery exercise. prepare by reviewing the contents of the pre-lab slm and completing the quiz associated with it. this ensures not only that you are properly prepared for the lab for your benefit, but that you have earned the privilege of learning anatomy through cadaveric study. the content of the ent anatomy lab was chosen by the week 52 faculty leads. the specific anatomy chosen will lay the foundation for your learning of week 52 content. the lab is three hours long and consists of four stations. you will spend 40 minutes at each station. there is no dissection. you will work with models, images, skulls, prosections, and selected completed dissections. at 11:40, when you have finished rotating through the four stations, you will clean up the lab. this includes proper moistening, wrapping and bagging of all wet specimens and wiping down all surfaces with cleaning solution. at 11:50, an app-based rat will take place. it will consist of 3 questions on each section of 21a for a total of 12 questions. there is a lot of content to review, and the time spent studying specimens in the lab will help to consolidate it in preparation for the rat. next 9:00-9:40 9:40-10:20 10:20-11:00 11:00-11:40 pairs 1 21.1 neck 21.2 pharynx & larynx 21.3 nose & oral cavity 21.4 skull & imaging pairs 2 21.2 pharynx & larynx 21.3 nose & oral cavity 21.4 skull & imaging 21.1 neck pairs 3 21.3 nose & oral cavity 21.4 skull & imaging 21.1 neck 21.2 pharynx & larynx pairs 4 21.4 skull & imaging 21.1 neck 21.2 pharynx & larynx 21.3 nose & oral cavity
attention this module is packing massive amounts of meme heat these memes are on fire these memes are hot are you feeling hot? #medsnothot next previous

author & emodule production: barbara ballyk, ph.d. associate professor, teaching stream division of anatomy, department of surgery faculty of medicine, university of toronto acknowledgements previous brand design: janet koecher, discovery commons university of toronto © 2017 emodule production: albert gheorghita, md candidate class of 2020 faculty of medicine, university of toronto valera castanov, ph.d. candidate faculty of medicine, university of toronto julian manzone, md candidate class of 2019 faculty of medicine, university of toronto

20.3 the nose and oral cavity previous specimens split skull model 4 half heads from cadaver 2 ; at least one was left undissected . next what you’ll need: pairs 4 will be the last at this station. they are responsible for returning the half heads to the correct cadaver at the end of the lab. remember that there is a tag on the ear with the cadaver number on it. use this number to match the head with the cadaver. pairs 3, who will start at this station, are responsible for retrieving the half head from their cadaver 2; i.e. pair a3 will retrieve the half head from cadaver a2, b3 will retrieve the half head from cadaver b2, etc. one of the half heads from each cadaver 2 will have had the floor of the mouth dissected and may or may not have had the nasal concha removed; this is the correct specimen to use for this exercise. instructions many slides in this module are “theory-dense”. the practical activities are limited to 6 slides. come having reviewed all slides and use you lab time wisely, focusing on the practical content on slides 4-6 and 13-15. pairs 4 will be the last at this station. moisten, wrap and bag the half heads and leave them on the table. reassemble the split skull model - don’t forget the nasal septum! spray and wipe down the table when you are finished.

21.3 objectives next previous when you have completed the exercises described here, you will be able to identify and describe the: paranasal sinuses. openings into the nasal cavities from the paranasal sinuses and the nasolacrimal duct. blood and nerve supply of the nasal mucosa, including the route by which the parent vessels and nerves gain access to the nasal cavities. boundaries of the oral cavity. locations of the palatine and lingual tonsils. 1 nerves glands, ducts and blood vessels of the floor of the mouth role of the chorda tympani and lingual nerves in delivering taste fibres to the anterior 2/3 of the tongue and parasympathetic fibres to the salivary glands in the floor of the mouth.

21.3 the nasal cavity next previous the nasal cavity extends from the nostrils (nares), anteriorly, to the choanae , posteriorly. the choanae are bilaterally-paired openings on either side of the nasal septum, that are continuous with the nasopharynx. each nasal cavity is described as having a floor, formed by the hard palate, a medial wall, formed by the nasal septum, a roof, and a lateral wall. choanae funnel 2

21.3 the paranasal air sinuses next previous 3 the paranasal air sinuses are cavities in the bones of the skull that open into the nasal cavity. they are lined by the same mucus membrane that lines the nasal cavity, and the mucus produced in these sinuses drains through these openings into the nasal cavities. the paranasal air sinuses are named according to the bone in which they are located. thus, they are the frontal sinus (a), ethmoidal air cells (b), maxillary sinus (c) and sphenoid sinus (see next slide). the sinuses of the ethmoid bone, the ethmoid air cells, consist of a group of small spaces, much like clusters of soap bubbles, within the lateral masses of the ethmoid bone. note in the lower diagram that they are located lateral to the sphenoethmoidal recess (d) and the superior (e) and middle (f) meatuses. the posterior ethmoid air cells open into the superior meatus (next slide).

the middle ethmoid air cells are located within the bulla and open onto its surface. the anterior ethmoid air cells open into the posterior part of the semilunar hiatus. 21.3 openings into the nasal cavity i next previous tas k in the half cadaver head, identify the sphenoid air sinus (a) and its opening into the sphenoethmoidal recess (arrow, b). tas k identify, in the middle meatus, the semilunar hiatus (c). identify the ethmoidal bulla (d), the raised area of the middle meatus superior to the semilunar hiatus. bulla bubble 4 at least one of the half heads will have the nasal concha intact. you can use this as a reference as you study the specimens in which the nasal concha have been removed.

5.2 the nasolacrimal duct previous 11a 21.3 openings into the nasal cavity ii next previous tas k using the tip of a blunt dissecting probe, locate the opening to the maxillary sinus approximately midway along the semilunar hiatus (e). the maxillary sinuses are the largest of the paranasal air sinuses. next locate the opening of the frontal sinus (f) at the anterior end of the semilunar hiatus. hiatus a gap tas k probe the anterior, superior, part of the inferior meatus and identify the opening of the nasolacrimal duct (g). this passage allows tears from the orbit to drain into the nasal cavity. tas k on a skull, locate the entrance of the nasolacrimal duct in the anterior, inferior, medial part of the orbit. use a pipe cleaner to probe in, and confirm the connection to the inferior meatus . 5

21.3 the sphenopalatine foramen next previous tas k locate the sphenopalatine foramen (b) which is, as the name suggests, an opening between the sphenoid and palatine bones (a). you will find it posterior to the cut edge of the middle concha. recall that this opening connects the nasal cavity with the pterygopalatine fossa. it is through this opening that branches of the maxillary nerve (c) and artery (d) gain access to the mucosa lining the nasal cavity. the next three slides are theory-based and do not require specimens; if lab time permits, review them together. if not, be sure you get to slides 13-15, which require lab specimens, and come back to them later. 6

21.3 the nerve supply to the nasal cavity next previous the maxillary nerve, v2, passes from the cranial cavity, via the foramen rotundum, into the pterygopalatine fossa. from there, its nasal branches pass through the sphenopalatine foramen into the mucosa of the nasal cavity. the lateral nasal branches (a) of the maxillary nerve (v2) supply much of the lateral wall of the nasal cavity. the nasopalatine branch (b) of the maxillary nerve (v2) crosses the roof of the nose from lateral to medial, from the sphenopalatine foramen to the mucosa of the nasal septum. the distal part of the nasopalatine nerve leaves the anterior part of the septum to pass through the incisive foramen (c) to innervate the anterior portion of the oral surface of the hard palate. thus, most of the nasal cavity is innervated by branches of the maxillary nerve, v2. 7 however, the anterior part of the lateral wall and septum is innervated by branches of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve, v1. (d).

21.3 the blood supply to the nasal cavity next previous the sphenopalatine artery (a), a branch of the maxillary artery (b) enters the mucosa of the nasal cavity via the sphenopalatine foramen. its lateral nasal branches (c) supply much of the lateral wall, and its septal branches (d) cross the roof of the nose to supply blood to the nasal septum. while most of the nasal mucosa receives blood from branches of the maxillary artery, branches of the ophthalmic artery (e) supply the olfactory part of the nasal mucosa, and branches of the facial artery (f) supply of the mucosa in the anterior part of the nose, and branches of the greater palatine artery (g) ascends via the incisive foramen to contribute to the supply of the anterior nasal septum these vessels anastomose freely within the nasal mucosa. the anastomoses in the info anterior, inferior, nasal septum between branches of the maxillary, facial and ophthalmic arteries are 8 particularly rich, and create a complex called keisselbach’s plexus (h), making this area particularly prone to nosebleeds (epistaxis). this area is commonly referred to as keisselbach’s area or little’s area. the majority of nosebleeds occur in this location.

21.3 summary: the blood and nerve supply to the nasal cavity next previous the figure on the right is a posterior view of a coronally-sectioned skull, looking outward through the right nasal cavity and piriform aperture. the maxillary nerve, v2, and artery (a) are shown in the pterygopalatine fossa, along with the pterygopalatine ganglion (b). the sphenopalatine artery and maxillary nerve give rise to lateral nasal branches (c). the nasopalatine branch (d) of the maxillary nerve and the septal branches (e) of the sphenopalatine artery cross the roof of the nasal cavity from lateral to medial, from the sphenopalatine foramen to the mucosa of the nasal septum. 9

21.2 progress check 1 next previous 10 since embarking on this exercise, you have identified the following structures and learned the answers to the following questions. what forms the floor, roof, lateral and medial walls of the nasal cavity? in the cadaver half head with the conchae intact, identify the superior, middle and inferior conchae, sphenoethmoidal recess, superior, middle and inferior meatuses. in the cadaver half head with the conchae removed, identify the sphenoid air sinus, sphenoethmoidal recess, middle meatus, semilunar hiatus, ethmoidal bulla, openings of the maxillary and frontal sinuses, opening of the nasolacrimal duct, sphenopalatine foramen. what two spaces are connected through the sphenopalatine foramen? what nerves and vessels pass through the sphenopalatine foramen? what nerve branches supply the medial and lateral walls of the nasal cavity? what blood vessels supply the medial and lateral walls of the nasal cavity? describe keisselbach’s plexus and its clinical significance. pause here to assess your learning. quiz each other thoroughly. if you are satisfied with your ability to identify these structures and answer these questions, move on to the next stage of the exercise.

21.3 the borders of the oral cavity next previous this schematic focuses on the oral cavity. notice that the oral cavity opens anteriorly at the oral fissure. its roof is formed by the hard palate, its floor is formed by the tongue and associated mucosa, and its lateral walls are formed by the cheeks. the oral cavity ends posteriorly at the oropharyngeal isthmus , which is the narrowing that leads to the oropharynx. the oropharyngeal isthmus is guarded by the soft palate, which, as depicted by the blue arrows in the diagram, is raised in swallowing to isolate the oropharynx from the nasopharynx. this ensures that food proceeds toward the digestive tract, and not upward into the nasal cavities. isthmus the portion of a space or structure where it narrows 11

21.3 the oral cavity, anterior view next previous the oropharyngeal isthmus is bounded by the soft palate superiorly, two pairs of mucosal folds laterally, and the base of the tongue inferiorly. the anterior member of each pair of mucosal folds is the palatoglossal fold (b) or anterior pillar, created by the underlying palatoglossus muscle. the posterior member of each pair is the palatopharyngeal fold (c) or posterior pillar, created by the palatopharyngeus muscle. between the palatoglossal and palatopharyngeal folds, lies a palatine tonsil (d). these tonsils are largest in children, atrophy with age, and may even have been removed during the lifetime of the cadaver you will study. palatopharyngeal related to the palate and the pharynx uvula little grape (l) tas k have your lab partner open their mouth and identify their soft palate (e), uvula (f), palatoglossal and palatopharyngeal folds, and if possible, their palatine tonsils. 12 palatoglossal related to the palate and the tongue; glossus (gr) = tongue

21.3 if you can name it, you can pierce it! upper (right) and lower (below) frenulum piercings. 4a 21.3 the oral vestibule next previous and turn down their lower lip and identify the superior and inferior labial frenulum in the midline of each . these are folds of mucous membrane that connect the lip to the gingiva. tas k ask your lab partner to lift their upper lip the oral cavity consists of the vestibule and the oral cavity proper. the oral vestibule is the space outside the teeth; it is therefore bounded by the lips and cheeks externally, and the teeth and gums (gingiva) internally. the oral cavity proper is the space contained within the alveolar processes and teeth. tas k ask your lab partner to stop doing that. 13

21.3 the oral cavity, midsagittal section next previous palatopharyngeal (b) folds and the tonsillar bed (c) in the bisected cadaver head. tas k identify the palatoglossal (a) and at least one of the bisected heads will have been left with the mucosa intact. 14

21.3 the floor of the mouth next previous tas k identify the sublingual salivary gland lying on the mylohyoid muscle. 15 the sublingual salivary glands have about a dozen short ducts that open directly into the floor of the mouth. in addition to taste fibres, the chorda tympani contributes parasympathetic preganglionic fibres to the lingual nerve. the lingual nerve carries them to the floor of the mouth, where they synapse on the submandibular ganglion. postganglionic fibres are distributed to the submandibular and sublingual glands, and the mucosa of the anterior 2/3 of the tongue and floor of the mouth locate the submandibular duct and trace it posteriorly to where it joins the deep part of the submandibular gland. identify and trace the lingual nerve crossing under the submandibular duct, from lateral to medial, as illustrated. the lingual nerve is a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve, v3. it is responsible for general sensation from that anterior 2/3 of the tongue. the lingual nerve also distributes taste fibres to thisregion that it receives from the chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve, cn vii. on each of the four bisected heads, pull the tongue laterally and assess the dissection of the floor of the mouth. choose the two that are best done for the following exercise.

21.3 the hypoglossal nerve next previous tas k medial to the lingual nerve (a), identify the vertically-oriented fibres of the hyoglossus muscle (b). 16 inferior to the lingual nerve, identify the hypoglossal nerve (d), running lateral to the hyoglossus. the lingual artery (e), a branch of the external carotid artery (f), passes medial to the hyoglossus. the fibres of the hyoglossus pass superiorly from the hyoid bone (c) to blend with the muscles of the tongue.

21.3 progress check 2 next previous 17 since the last progress check, you have identified the following structures and learned the answers to the following questions. what forms the floor, roof, lateral and medial walls of the oral cavity? what is the oropharyngeal isthmus and what structures form its borders? in your lab partner’s oral cavity, identify their oral vestibule and oral cavity proper, superior and inferior labial frenula, lingual frenulum, soft palate, uvula, palatoglossal and palatopharyngeal folds, and palatine tonsils. in the cadaveric half head, identify the palatoglossal and palatopharyngeal folds, and the tonsillar bed. lateral to the tongue in the dissected floor of the mouth, identify the sublingual salivary gland, mylohyoid muscle, submandibular duct, lingual nerve (function and distribution? relationship to the chorda tympani?) and hypoglossal nerve. if you are satisfied with your ability to identify these structures and answer these questions, call your ta over for confirmation and for permission to move on.
previous 21.3 quiz 16 i have the sauce, go to the quiz no, i have ketchup, skip the quiz do you have enough sauce to carry on to the quiz? next

congratulations on finishing lab 21.3 the nose and oral cavity! review exercise 21.3 review exercise 21.3 review exercise 21.3 previous back to labs selection back to labs selection back to labs selection

21.2 the pharynx & larynx previous specimens larynx models, with and without muscles prosected pharynx prosected larynx half heads from cadaver 2 ; at least one was left undissected next what you’ll need: pairs 3 will be the last at this station. moisten, wrap and bag the half heads and leave them on the table. spray and wipe down the table when you are finished. pairs 2, who will start at this station, are responsible for retrieving the half head from their cadaver 2; i.e. pair a2 will retrieve the half head from cadaver a2, b2 will retrieve the half head from cadaver b2, etc. if the floor of the mouth is dissected on the half head, it belongs at station 3. otherwise it belongs at station 2. it may or may not have had the mucosa covering the pharyngeal wall removed. instructions pairs 3 will be the last at this station. moisten, wrap and bag the half heads and the prosections and leave them on the table. spray and wipe down the table when you are finished.

21.2 objectives next previous 1 when you have completed the exercises described here, you will be able to identify and describe the: subdivisions of the pharynx, including their major features. vocal and vestibular ligaments, and their relationships to the membranes of the larynx intrinsic muscles of the larynx, including their actions and nerve supply

21.2 overview of the pharynx next previous the pharynx is a passage common to both the respiratory and digestive systems. it extends from the base of the skull to the inferior border of the cricoid cartilage at the level of the 6th cervical vertebra. there are 3 layers to its wall; the inner mucosa, the middle muscular layer, and an outer layer of ct called the buccopharyngeal fascia. the pharynx opens anteriorly and is subdivided into 3 regions accordingly: 1. the nasopharynx opens into the nasal cavity. the nasopharynx extends from the base of the skull to the tip of the soft palate. 2. the oropharynx opens into the mouth. the oropharynx extends from the tip of the soft palate to the upper margin of the epiglottis. 3. the laryngopharynx opens into the larynx. the laryngopharynx extends from the margin of the epiglottis to the lower border of the cricoid cartilage. epiglottis epi = above; glottis = the vocal cords and the space between them 2

21.2 the subdivisions of the pharynx next previous tas k on the bisected cadaver head that has not been dissected, the cut edge of the body of the sphenoid on the base of the skull, the soft palate, the epiglottis, the cut posterior edge of the cricoid cartilage. using these landmarks, identify the 3 subdivisions of the pharynx. in the nasopharynx, identify the opening of the pharyngotympanic (pt) tube (auditory tube, or, eustacian tube). recall that the pharyngotympanic tube connects the nasopharynx with the middle ear. 3 identify the following landmarks:

21.2 the pharyngotympanic tube: clinical next previous otitis media info the wall of the pharyngotympanic tube where it opens into the middle ear is supported by elastic cartilage, which confers the ability of the tube to open and close. the tube is usually closed except equilibration of pressure across the tympanic membrane info the pharyngotympanic tube also allows a route through which air pressure in the middle ear can equilibrate with atmospheric pressure. most have experienced the action of the pharyngotympanic 4 when pressure increases in the nasopharynx, or, during swallowing and yawning, when the action of several muscles attaching around the tube create traction on the opening. the middle ear is lined with a mucous membrane, and the pharyngotympanic tube provides a route for drainage of the fluid produced by the membrane. inflammation of the mucosa in the tube can interfere with normal drainage leading to fluid build-up in the middle ear. this can provide a medium for bacterial growth, leading to ear infection (otitis media). the pharyngotympanic tube is shorter, more horizontal, and narrower in children, making them prone to recurring middle ear infections. the fluid build-up in the middle ear with recurring middle ear infections in children may impair conductive hearing. to prevent this it sometimes becomes necessary to insert tympanostomy tubes through the tympanic membrane in order to provide an alternate route for drainage. tube when taking off in an aeroplane. as ambient pressure begins to drop, the air trapped in the middle ear will expand, distorting the tympanic membrane, creating a sensation of pressure. when the pharyngotympanic tube opens the pressure of air in the middle ear equilibrates with atmospheric pressure and the sensation is relieved.

21.2 features of the nasopharynx next previous torus tubarius around the opening to the pharyngotympanic tube. tas k identify the raised margin called the pharyngeal recess superior and posterior to the torus tas k observe the adenoids info enlarged pharyngeal tonsils are called adenoids. adenoids can obstruct the torus = a round moulding tubarius = of the tube adenoid relating to a gland 5 this is created by mucosa covering the elastic cartilage at the opening of the tube. flow of air through the choanae, making it necessary to breathe through the mouth. tubaris. the pharyngeal tonsils lie in the pharyngeal recess.

21.2 features of the oropharynx and laryngopharynx next previous palatopharyngeal fold and palatine tonsil at the junction of the tas k in the oropharynx, identify the 6 oral cavity with the oropharynx. note that the posterior one third of the tongue (approximately) faces into the oropharynx. identify the valleculae , spaces located between the tongue and the epiglottis. the two valleculae are separated by the median glossoepiglottic fold. identify the median glossoepiglottic fold. depending on how the head was bisected, it might be located on the other half. next, confirm that the laryngopharynx opens into the larynx anteriorly and the esophagus inferiorly. identify the aryepiglottic fold forming the margin of the laryngeal inlet and the piriform recess, the space that lies lateral to it. vallecula valley piriform pear-shaped

21.2 nerve supply to the pharynx next previous motor control of the pharynx, and therefore swallowing, comes predominantly from the vagus nerve. sensation from the pharyngeal mucosa is carried from the: nasopharynx by pharyngeal branches of the maxillary nerve, oropharynx by the glossopharyngeal nerve, and laryngopharynx by the internal laryngeal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve, a branch of the vagus nerve. 7

21.2 the interior of the pharynx next previous the nasopharynx, oropharynx, laryngopharynx, and esophagus. tas k open the pharynx and locate unwrap the prosected pharynx. the posterior pharyngeal wall in this specimen has been divided along the midline raphe connecting the constrictors of each side. identify the nasal septum, choanae, torus tubarius, the position of the pharyngeal tonsil, the soft palate, and the uvula . identify the palatoglossal folds, posterior third of the tongue, lingual tonsil, and the epiglottis. between the root of the tongue and the epiglottis identify the valleculae and the median and lateral glossoepiglottic folds. in the laryngopharynx, find the location of the posterior surface of the cricoid cartilage (the lamina). identify the aryepiglottic folds passing from the cricoid to the epiglottis on each side and flanking the inlet to the larynx. lateral to the aryepiglottic folds on each side, identify the piriform fossae. uvula “grape” 8

21.2 progress check 1 next previous 9 since embarking on this exercise, you have identified the following structures and learned the answers to the following questions. name the three layers of the pharyngeal wall. name the three subdivisions of the pharynx and describe the borders between them. describe the relationship between the pharyngotympanic tube and otitis media. how does the structure of the tube differ in children, as compared to adults? how does this increases the incidence of otitis media in children? describe the role of the tube in balancing pressure across the tympanic membrane. in the half head, identify the opening of the pharyngotympanic tube, the torus tubarius, pharyngeal recess, the location of the pharyngeal tonsils. what are adenoids? identify the palatopharyngeal fold, palatine tonsil, vallecula, median glossoepiglottic fold, aryepiglottic fold and piriform recess. describe the sensory and motor nerve supply to the pharynx. in the prosected pharynx, identify the subdivisions of the pharynx, the nasal septum, choanae, torus tubarius, location of the pharyngeal tonsil, the soft palate, the uvula, palatoglossal folds, posterior third of the tongue, lingual tonsil, epiglottis, valleculae, median and lateral glossoepiglottic folds, the lamina of the cricoid cartilage, aryepiglottic folds, inlet to the larynx, and the piriform fossae pause here to assess your learning. quiz each other thoroughly. if you are satisfied with your ability to identify these structures and answer these questions, move on to the next stage of the exercise.

21.2 overview of the larynx next previous the larynx is a structure that serves the dual functions of supporting the airway and producing sound. the skeleton of the larynx consists of a series of articulated cartilages that maintain the patency of the airway at this level and which give attachment to membranes, ligaments, and muscles necessary for the production of sound. 10 patency an state of openness

21.2 the thyrohyoid membrane next previous between the hyoid bone and superior border of the thyroid cartilage. the superior laryngeal nerve penetrates the lateral tas k unwrap the prosected larynx. locate the thyrohyoid membrane 11 part of the thyrohyoid membrane to deliver sensory nerve fibres to the laryngeal mucosa above the level of the vocal folds. between the 2 cricothyroid muscles, identify the median cricothyroid ligament. it may have been pierced with a needle by paramedics training on cadavers to perform cricothyrotomy.

21.2 the cricothyroid membrane and the vocal ligament next previous the median cricothyroid ligament spreads out laterally on each side as the cricothyroid ligaments, sheet-like membranes that arise from the lateral margins of the cricoid and extend superiorly to meet the vocal ligaments. the vocal ligaments stretch from the vocal process of each arytenoid cartilage to attach to the thyroid cartilage just below the attachment of the epiglottis. the cricothyroid ligament is sometimes referred to as the cricovocal membrane, or, conus elasticus. locate the cricothyroid membranes and the vocal ligaments. the vocal ligaments are essentially, the free margins of the cricothyroid membranes on each side of the larynx. tas k on the model of the larynx, 12

21.2 the quadrangular membrane and the vestibular ligament next previous the quadrangular membrane is an elastic membrane, which connects the lateral edge of the epiglottis to the arytenoid cartilage on each side. the inferior free edge of the quadrangular membrane is called the vestibular ligament. tas k on the model of the larynx, and on the prosection of the larynx, locate the quadrangular membranes and vestibular ligaments. 13

21.2 the mucosal lining of the larynx forms the vocal cords next previous the internal surface of the larynx is covered with mucous membrane. the mucous membrane drapes over the quadrangular membrane, creating the aryepiglottic fold. it then tucks under the vestibular ligament forming the vestibular fold, or, false vocal cord. 14 the mucosa then comes back medially to cover the vocal ligament, forming the vocal fold, or, true vocal cord, before passing inferiorly onto the internal surface of the cricothyroid ligament.

21.2 the vocal folds in the cadaver next previous and aryepiglottic folds. locate the false vocal cords (vestibular folds) and the true vocal cords (vocal folds) tas k on the prosection of the larynx with vessels, locate the epiglottis cadaver head, identify the aryepiglottic fold and the tas k using the bisected 15 review the piriform fossa lateral to it and the true and false vocal folds.

21.2 intrinsic muscles of the larynx i next previous sound is produced when the rima glottidis is closed, forcing air to rapidly flow past the true vocal folds, causing them to vibrate. sound is modulated by the tension and position of the vocal cords. the tension and position of the vocal cords is controlled by the intrinsic muscles of the larynx . 16 tas k on the model of the larynx and on the prosected larynx specimen, identify the posterior cricoarytenoid muscle passing from the posterior surface of the cricoid lamina to the muscular process of the arytenoid cartilage. this abducts the vocal cords by causing the vocal process to rotate outwards. it is the only muscle that does so, thereby opening the rima glottidis. the rima glottidis opens when we breathe. identify the lateral cricoarytenoid muscle, attaching the cricoid ring to the muscular process of the arytenoid. it rotates the vocal process inwards, thereby adducting the vocal cord. this occurs when we swallow and is necessary for the larynx to produce sound. on the model of the larynx only, identify the arytenoid muscles connecting the two arytenoid cartilages to each other. these muscles have both oblique and transverse parts and function to draw the arytenoid cartilages closer together, helping to close the rima glottidis. this occurs when we swallow and is necessary for the larynx to produce sound. intrinsic muscles of the larynx… …have attachments confined to the laryngeal cartilages. when they contract, they move the laryngeal cartilages relative to each other, and therefore move the vocal cords relative to each other - opened, closed, stretched, relaxed. the cricothyroid, for instance, tilts the thyroid cartilage anteriorly, increasing the tension on the vocal folds and raising the pitch of the voice.

21.2 intrinsic muscles of the larynx ii next previous tas k on the model of the larynx and on the prosected larynx specimen, identify the thyroarytenoid muscle, passing between the thyroid and arytenoid cartilages. it draws the thyroid and arytenoid cartilages closer, reducing the tension on the vocal cords and thereby lowering the pitch of the voice. 17

21.2 the vagus nerves innervate the larynx next previous the intrinsic muscles of the larynx are all innervated by somatic motor fibres carried in branches of the vagus nerve. the superior laryngeal nerve is a branch of the vagus nerve. its external laryngeal branch innervates the cricothyroid muscle. its internal laryngeal branch is sensory to the laryngeal mucosa above the vocal folds. the recurrent laryngeal nerves innervate all other intrinsic muscles of the larynx and supplies sensory fibres to the laryngeal mucosa of the infraglottic space. tas k on the prosection of the larynx with vessels, locate the recurrent laryngeal nerves. they lie along the groove where the 18 esophagus meets the trachea. trace them superiorly to where they pass deep to the inferior constrictor muscle. at this point they enter the larynx and may be referred to as the inferior laryngeal nerves.

21.2 progress check 2 next previous 19 since the last progress check, you have identified the following structures and learned the answers to the following questions. on the model of the larynx, locate the cricothyroid membranes (conus elasticus) and vocal ligaments, the quadrangular membranes and vestibular ligaments. in the prosected larynx, identify the thyrohyoid membrane, cricothyroid muscles, median cricothyroid ligament, the quadrangular membranes and vestibular ligaments. in the prosected larynx with vessels, identify the epiglottis, aryepiglottic folds, false vocal cords (vestibular folds) and true vocal cords (vocal folds). in the bisected cadaver head, identify the aryepiglottic fold, piriform fossae, and the true and false vocal folds. what, in general, do the intrinsic muscles of the larynx do? on the model and prosection, identify the posterior cricoarytenoid muscle, (action?), lateral cricoarytenoid muscle, (action?), and thyroarytenoid muscle (action?). on the model, only, identify the arytenoid muscles (action?). describe the sensory and motor innervation of the larynx. if you are satisfied with your ability to identify these structures and answer these questions, call your ta over for confirmation and for permission to move on.

21.1 the neck previous specimens two cadavers 1 next what you’ll need: instructions the two best neck dissections completed in your lab in recent weeks have been chosen for your use in this lab. pairs 1 from groups a and b will start on one and pairs 1 from groups c and d will work on the other. this pattern will be maintained through the rotations. in all cases, explore both sides of the dissection looking for the structure in question. it could be on one side, the other or both. pairs 2 will finish at this station. ensure there is no block under the cadaver, and then moisten and cover the cadaver, and zip the bag shut.

21.1 objectives next previous when you have completed the exercises described here, you will be able to identify and describe the: location and extent of the parotid gland and the course of its duct. attachments, actions and nerve supply of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. larynx within the context of the neck. submandibular gland in the context of the neck. accessory nerve, and its relationship to the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles. hypoglossal nerve, including its relationship in the neck to the external carotid artery and the stylohyoid, posterior belly of the digastric, and mylohyoid muscles gross structure, blood supply and venous drainage of the thyroid and parathyroid glands sensory and motor nerve supply to the larynx vagus nerve, recurrent laryngeal nerve and phrenic nerve 1

next previous 21.1 the parotid gland & duct 2 a muscle of mastication, extending from the zygomatic arch (d) to the angle of the mandible. identify the masseter muscle (b), tas k your first task will be to identify the parotid duct (a) superficial to the masseter muscle (c). identify the parotid duct, about a finger’s breadth inferior to the zygomatic arch, and running roughly parallel to it. follow the parotid duct posteriorly and identify the anterior border of the parotid gland itself. notice the extent of the gland, extending from the zygomatic arch to the angle of the mandible. observe that it overlaps both the masseter muscle and the ramus of the mandible. it is enclosed in a dense connective tissue capsule that is richly-endowed with pain-reporting nerve fibres. you may notice branches of the facial nerve (b) emerging from the parotid gland to innervate muscles of facial expression. next, follow the parotid duct anteriorly as it crosses the anterior border of the masseter to pierce the buccinator muscle to open into the oral vestibule opposite to the upper second molar tooth. an exceptional dissection demonstrating all motor branches of the facial nerve is available in grant’s museum.

21.1 the sternocleidomastoid muscle (scm) next previous tas k identify the sternocleidomastoid muscle (a) and trace it from the mastoid process (b) of the temporal bone to its attachments to the manubrium (c) and medial clavicle (d). note that the attachment to the manubrium is tendinous but the attachment to the clavicle is fleshy. tas k turn your head to the left and palpate the inferior attachments of the right sternocleidomastoid to confirm its tendinous attachment to the manubrium and its fleshy attachment to the clavicle. 3 the scm functions to turns the head to the opposite side

21.1 the larynx in the neck next previous the larynx guards the entrance to the respiratory tract and permits phonation. its skeleton is cartilaginous. two of the larger cartilages of the larynx are the thyroid (a) and cricoid (b) cartilages. the structure of the thyroid and cricoid cartilages are the subject of exercise 21.2. the purpose here is to understand the position of the larynx in the context of the neck. in the cadaver, palpate the thyroid (a) and cricoid (b) cartilages. identify the laryngeal tas k palpate the hyoid bone on the cadaver. the hyoid bone, with the thyroid and cricoid cartilages, contribute to the skeleton of the larynx. the hyoid is an unusual bone because it does not form a joint with any other bone. instead, it is suspended between the mandible and the thyroid cartilage by muscles, ligaments, and membranes. 4 prominence (c) and the superior thyroid notch (d) of the thyroid cartilage. identify the narrow anterior lamina of the cricoid cartilage (e). tas k

21.1 the submandibular gland in the neck next previous tas k identify the superficial part of the submandibular salivary gland (a) between the posterior fibres of mylohyoid and the body of the mandible. the submandibular salivary gland wraps around the posterior border of the mylohyoid muscle (b), so that its deep part (c) comes to lie within the floor of the mouth. the duct of the gland (d) is explored with the oral cavity, in exercise 21.3. for the submandibular and sublingual glands (e), preganglionic parasympathetic fibers that are secretomotor for salivation are carried in the chorda tympani branch (f) of the facial nerve (vii). the chorda tympani joins the lingual branch (g) of the mandibular nerve (v3), which delivers the parasympathetic preganglionic fibres into the floor of the mouth. the preganglionic fibers synapse in the submandibular ganglion (h) on the lingual nerve, and the postganglionic fibers enter the glands and supply the mucosa in the floor of the mouth. 5

21.1 the accessory nerve next previous on one side of the cadaver, the scm has been transected about 5 cm superior to its attachment to the clavicle. trace the accessory nerve posteriorly to the trapezius muscle. recall that the accessory nerve innervates the scm and trapezius muscles, and is tested with the “shoulder shrug” and “head turn” maneuvers. 6 tas k reflect the scm superiorly. identify the accessory nerve where it enters the deep surface of the scm, and trace it superiorly as far as possible. recall that it exits the cranium through the jugular foramen with the glossopharyngeal (c.n. ix) vagus (c.n. x) nerves.

21.1 the hypoglossal nerve next previous tas k by palpation, identify the tip of the greater horn of the hyoid bone. between it and the posterior belly of the digastric, identify and outline the hypoglossal nerve. follow the nerve as it sweeps inferior to the posterior belly of the digastric, and crosses the carotid drowsy (gr); the compression of this artery made people lose consciousness 7 external carotid artery before it passes medial to the digastric and enters the mouth deep to the mylohyoid muscle.

21.1 the thyroid and parathyroid glands next previous tas k identify the lobe of the thyroid gland recall that two parathyroid glands, superior and inferior, normally lie on the posterior surface of each lobe of the thyroid gland. however, these are structures that migrate to their position during embryological development and so occasionally one or more of these glands may be found in other locations. the parathyroid glands are essential in the regulation of calcium levels in the body and each has a diameter of about 5 mm. it is not necessary to identify these glands. 8 and outline the isthmus, which connects the lobe to its opposite member on the other side of the cadaver. is there a pyramidal lobe in your cadaver?

21.1 the cricothyroid muscle and cricothyrotomy next previous tas k identify the cricothyroid muscle passing between the thyroid and cricoid cartilages. cricothyrotomy info medial to the cricothyroid muscle identify the crico-thyroid ligament, which is pierced during cricothyrotomy, an emergency procedure for opening an airway in a patient obstructed above the level of the cricoid. 9

21.1 the superior laryngeal nerve next previous tas k identify the thyrohyoid membrane connecting the superior border of the thyroid cartilage and hyoid bone. recall, and if possible, identify, the internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve. it pierces the thyrohyoid membrane adjacent to the posterior margin 10 of the thyrohyoid muscle. the superior laryngeal nerve is a branch of the vagus nerve. its internal laryngeal branch pieces the thyrohyoid membrane to supply sensory fibres to the mucosa of the larynx above the level of the vocal cords. trace the internal laryngeal nerve superiorly to the point at which it passes deep to the external carotid artery and try to identify the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve, which arises near this point. the external laryngeal nerve passes inferiorly, in the company of the superior thyroid artery, to end by innervating the cricothyroid muscle and the inferior constrictor muscle of the pharynx.

21.1 the recurrent laryngeal nerve next previous the remainder of the sensory and motor innervation to the larynx is provided by another branch of the vagus, the recurrent laryngeal nerve. the right recurrent laryngeal nerve arises from the right vagus as it crosses the right subclavian artery to enter into the thorax. it recurs under the right subclavian artery. the left recurrent laryngeal nerve arises from the left vagus as it crosses the arch of the aorta in the thorax. it recurs under the aortic arch. both nerves ascend to the larynx in the groove between the trachea and esophagus. recur turn back; the recurrent laryngeal nerves turn and travel back toward the origin of the vagus nerve 11

21.1 the recurrent laryngeal nerve next previous tas k reflect the thyroid gland and identify the trachea. locate the recurrent laryngeal nerve at the intrinsic muscles of the larynx are the muscles that move the laryngeal cartilages relative to each other. they tend to change the quality of the sounds produced. the external muscles of the larynx move the larynx as a whole. the suprahyoid and infrahyoid muscles are external muscles of the larynx. 12 posterior edge of the trachea, where it meets the esophagus. recall that each recurrent laryngeal nerve innervates all of the intrinsic muscles of the larynx , except the cricothyroid and is sensory to the mucosa of the larynx below the vocal cords on its half of the larynx.

21.1 the superior thyroid artery next previous tas k identify the superior thyroid artery descending alongside the larynx to the apex of the thyroid gland. the superior thyroid artery is the first branch of the external carotid artery, and contributes to the blood supply of the thyroid and parathyroid glands. 13

21.1 the inferior thyroid artery next previous trace it superiorly and identify the inferior thyroid artery branching from it. trace the inferior thyroid artery to the thyroid gland. it, too, also supplies the parathyroid glands. tas k locate the thyrocervical trunk arising from the subclavian artery. like most endocrine organs, the thyroid gland has an abundant blood supply and rich anastomoses, in its case from the superior thyroid branches of the external carotid arteries and from the inferior thyroid branches of the subclavian arteries via the thyrocervical trunks. the thyroid ima artery info in addition, in a small but significant proportion of people, the thyroid receives ima lowest 14 a branch called the thyroid ima artery. this is a midline vessel which ascends to the thyroid isthmus from the brachiocephalic or common carotid arteries, or, sometimes even from the arch of the aorta. it is an important variant to remember in surgeries involving the thyroid gland or trachea.

21.1 venous drainage from the thyroid gland next previous venous drainage from the thyroid gland is via the superior and middle thyroid veins that enter the internal jugular veins, and the inferior thyroid veins that enter the brachiocephalic veins. these will have been removed during the process of dissection. 15

21.1 the vagus and phrenic nerves in the neck next previous common carotid artery, locate the vagus nerve. tas k between the internal jugular vein and 16 lateral to the internal jugular vein identify and outline the phrenic nerve on the anterior surface of the anterior scalene muscle. the phrenic nerve is formed by contributions from the anterior primary rami of the 3rd, 4th and 5th cervical spinal nerves.

21.1 progress check next previous 17 since embarking on this exercise, you have identified the following structures and learned the answers to the following questions. for muscles, describe their action(s) and innervation, for nerves, describe their function and distribution parotid gland and duct (where does the parotid duct open?), masseter muscle, branch(es) of the facial nerve, sternocleidomastoid muscle, accessory nerve the laryngeal prominence, superior thyroid notch, anterior lamina of the cricoid cartilage, hyoid bone submandibular gland (course of parasympathetic innervation?), external carotid artery, hypoglossal nerve, mylohyoid muscle thyroid gland and isthmus; what is the pyramidal lobe of the thyroid gland? how many parathyroid glands are usually present? where are they located? cricothyroid muscle, cricothyroid ligament; what is a cricothyrotomy? thyrohyoid membrane; function and distribution of the internal and external branches of the superior laryngeal nerve? identify the recurrent laryngeal nerve (function and distribution?) superior and inferior thyroid arteries; what is the thyroid ima artery? describe the venous drainage of the thyroid gland internal jugular vein, vagus nerve, common carotid artery; anterior scalene muscle and phrenic nerve; what are the spinal nerve roots of the phrenic nerve? if you are satisfied with your ability to identify these structures and answer these questions, call your ta over for confirmation and for permission to move on.

21a pre-lab slm part 1: the neck previous next

next previous 21a the parotid gland & duct 2 in the lab you will identify the parotid duct (a) superficial to the masseter muscle (c). recall that the parotid duct opens into the oral vestibule opposite the upper second molar. recall that the masseter is a muscle of mastication, extending from the zygomatic arch (d) to the angle of the mandible. like all muscles of mastication, it is innervated by branches of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve. in the lab you may notice branches of the facial nerve (b) arising from the anterior border of the parotid gland. recall that motor branches of the facial nerve supply the muscles of facial expression.

21a the submandibular gland next previous in the lab you will identify the submandibular salivary gland (a) between the posterior fibres of mylohyoid and the body of the mandible. recall that the submandibular gland wraps around the posterior border of the mylohyoid muscle (b), so that its deep part (c) comes to lie within the floor of the mouth. for the submandibular and sublingual glands (e), preganglionic parasympathetic fibers that are secretomotor for salivation are carried in the chorda tympani branch (f) of the facial nerve (vii). the chorda tympani joins the lingual branch (g) of the mandibular nerve (v3), which delivers the parasympathetic preganglionic fibres into the floor of the mouth. the preganglionic fibers synapse in the submandibular ganglion (h) on the lingual nerve, and the postganglionic fibers enter the glands and supply the mucosa in the floor of the mouth. 3

21a the accessory nerve next previous 4 in the lab you will identify the sternocleidomastoid muscle (scm), trapezius muscle and the accessory nerve, cranial nerve xi. recall that the scm acts to turn the head to the opposite side and that the trapezius muscle acts to elevate the shoulder. both are innervated by the accessory nerve, cranial nerve xi. recall how the actions of these muscles are used in the clinical assessment of c.n. xi.

21a the hypoglossal nerve next previous in the lab you will identify the hypoglossal nerve between the tip of the greater horn of the hyoid bone and the posterior belly of the digastric. you will review its course superficial to the external carotid artery before it passes medial to the digastric to enter the mouth deep to the mylohyoid muscle. 5 recall that the hypoglossal nerve is motor to the tongue, and how the movement of the tongue is used to assess this nerve’s function.

21a the thyroid and parathyroid glands next previous recall that the thyroid gland is comprised of two lobes joined by an isthmus. recall that two parathyroid glands, superior and inferior, normally lie on the posterior surface of each lobe of the thyroid gland. since these are structures that migrate to their position during embryological development, occasionally one or more of these glands may be found in other locations. the parathyroid glands are essential in the regulation of calcium levels in the body and each has a diameter of about 5 mm. 6

21a blood supply to the thyroid and parathyroid glands next previous the superior thyroid artery descends alongside the larynx to the apex of the thyroid gland. it is the first branch of the external carotid artery. the inferior thyroid artery branches from the thyrocervical trunk, itself a branch of the subclavian artery. like most endocrine organs, the thyroid and parathyroid glands have an abundant blood supply and rich anastomoses, in its case from the superior thyroid branches of the external carotid arteries and from the inferior thyroid branches of the subclavian arteries via the thyrocervical trunks. in addition, in a small but significant proportion of people, the thyroid gland receives a branch called the thyroid ima artery. this is a midline vessel which ascends to the thyroid isthmus from the brachiocephalic or common carotid arteries, or, sometimes even from the arch of the aorta. it is an important variant to remember in surgeries involving the thyroid gland or trachea. 7 ima lowest

21a venous drainage from the thyroid gland next previous venous drainage from the thyroid and parathyroid glands is via the superior and middle thyroid veins that enter the internal jugular veins, and the inferior thyroid veins that enter the brachiocephalic veins. 8
next previous 21a pre-lab slm part 2: the pharynx and larynx

next previous 10 21a overview of the pharynx the pharynx is a passage common to both the respiratory and digestive systems. it extends from the base of the skull to the inferior border of the cricoid cartilage at the level of the 6th cervical vertebra. there are 3 layers to its wall; the inner mucosa, the middle muscular layer, and an outer layer of ct called the buccopharyngeal fascia. the pharynx opens anteriorly and is subdivided into 3 regions accordingly: 1. the nasopharynx opens into the nasal cavity. the nasopharynx extends from the base of the skull to the tip of the soft palate. 2. the oropharynx opens into the mouth. the oropharynx extends from the tip of the soft palate to the upper margin of the epiglottis. 3. the laryngopharynx opens into the larynx. the laryngopharynx extends from the margin of the epiglottis to the lower border of the cricoid cartilage. epiglottis epi = above; glottis = the vocal cords and the space between them

21a features of the pharynx next previous an important feature of the nasopharynx is the opening of the pharyngotympanic (pt) tube (auditory tube, or, eustacian tube). recall that the pharyngotympanic tube connects the nasopharynx with the middle ear. 11 superior and posterior to the opening of the pt tube is the pharyngeal recess, in the roof of which is the pharyngeal tonsil. enlarged pharyngeal tonsils are called adenoids. adenoids can obstruct the flow of air through the choanae, making it necessary to breathe through the mouth. in the oropharynx, located between the palatoglossal and palatopharyngeal folds is the tonsillar bed, the location of the bilaterally-paired palatine tonsils. the lingual tonsils are located deep to the mucosa overlying the posterior 1/3 of the tongue. together, the pharyngeal, palatine and lingual tonsils form the ring of waldeyer, which guards the entrance to the digestive and respiratory tracts from antigen. adenoid relating to a gland; e.g. an adenoma is a cancer arising from glandular tissue.

21a the pharyngotympanic tube: clinical next previous otitis media info the wall of the pharyngotympanic tube where it opens into the middle ear is supported by elastic cartilage, which confers the ability of the tube to open and close. the tube is usually closed except equilibration of pressure across the tympanic membrane info the pharyngotympanic tube also allows a route through which air pressure in the middle ear can equilibrate with atmospheric pressure. most have experienced the action of the pharyngotympanic 12 when pressure increases in the nasopharynx, or, during swallowing and yawning, when the action of several muscles attaching around the tube create traction on the opening. the middle ear is lined with a mucous membrane, and the pharyngotympanic tube provides a route for drainage of the fluid produced by the membrane. inflammation of the mucosa in the tube can interfere with normal drainage leading to fluid build-up in the middle ear. this can provide a medium for bacterial growth, leading to ear infection (otitis media). the pharyngotympanic tube is shorter, more horizontal, and narrower in children, making them prone to recurring middle ear infections. the fluid build-up in the middle ear with recurring middle ear infections in children may impair conductive hearing. to prevent this it sometimes becomes necessary to insert tympanostomy tubes through the tympanic membrane in order to provide an alternate route for drainage. tube when taking off in an aeroplane. as ambient pressure begins to drop, the air trapped in the middle ear will expand, distorting the tympanic membrane, creating a sensation of pressure. when the pharyngotympanic tube opens the pressure of air in the middle ear equilibrates with atmospheric pressure and the sensation is relieved.

21a nerve supply to the pharynx next previous motor control of the pharynx, and therefore swallowing, comes predominantly from the vagus nerve. sensation from the pharyngeal mucosa is carried from the: nasopharynx by pharyngeal branches of the maxillary nerve, oropharynx by pharyngeal branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve, and laryngopharynx by the internal laryngeal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve, a branch of the vagus nerve. 13

21a overview of the larynx next previous the larynx is a structure that serves the dual functions of supporting the airway and producing sound. the skeleton of the larynx consists of a series of articulated cartilages that maintain the patency of the airway at this level and which give attachment to membranes, ligaments, and muscles necessary for the production of sound. 14 patency an state of openness

21a the cricothyroid membrane and the vocal ligament next previous the cricothyroid ligaments are sheet-like membranes that arise from the lateral margins of the cricoid and extend superiorly to meet the vocal ligaments. the vocal ligaments stretch from the vocal process of each arytenoid cartilage to attach to the thyroid cartilage just below the attachment of the epiglottis. the vocal ligaments are essentially, the free margins of the cricothyroid membranes on each side of the larynx. 15 a.k.a. cricovocal membrane or conus elasticus the quadrangular membrane is an elastic membrane, which connects the lateral edge of the epiglottis to the arytenoid cartilage on each side. the inferior free edge of the quadrangular membrane is called the vestibular ligament.

21a the mucosal lining of the larynx forms the vocal cords next previous the internal surface of the larynx is covered with mucous membrane. the mucous membrane drapes over the quadrangular membrane, creating the aryepiglottic fold. it then tucks under the vestibular ligament forming the vestibular fold, or, false vocal cord. 16 the mucosa then comes back medially to cover the vocal ligament, forming the vocal fold, or, true vocal cord, before passing inferiorly onto the internal surface of the cricothyroid ligament.

21a intrinsic muscles of the larynx i next previous when the vocal folds are adducted, the rima glottidis is closed. this is the position of the vocal folds when we swallow, as it guards against food entering the larynx. in addition, in this position, expelled air is forced to flow rapidly past the true vocal folds causing them to vibrate, and producing sound. sound is modulated by the tension and position of the vocal cords. 17 when the vocal folds are abducted, the rima glottidis opens, and we can breathe. the tension and position of the vocal cords is controlled by the intrinsic muscles of the larynx . the posterior cricoarytenoid muscle abducts the vocal cords by causing the vocal process of the arytenoid cartilage to rotate outwards. it is the only muscle that does so, thereby opening the rima glottidis when we breathe. the lateral cricoarytenoid muscle rotates the vocal process of the arytenoid cartilage inwards, thereby adducting the vocal cord. the arytenoid muscles function to draw the arytenoid cartilages closer together, helping to close the rima glottidis. this occurs when we swallow and is necessary for the larynx to produce sound. the thyroarytenoid muscles draw the thyroid and arytenoid cartilages closer, reducing the tension on the vocal cords and thereby lowering the pitch of the voice. intrinsic muscles of the larynx… …have attachments confined to the laryngeal cartilages. when they contract, they move the laryngeal cartilages relative to each other, and therefore move the vocal cords relative to each other - opened, closed, stretched, relaxed. the cricothyroid, for instance, tilts the thyroid cartilage anteriorly, increasing the tension on the vocal folds and raising the pitch of the voice.

21a the vagus nerves innervate the larynx next previous the intrinsic muscles of the larynx are all innervated by somatic motor fibres carried in branches of the vagus nerve. the superior laryngeal nerve is a branch of the vagus nerve. its external laryngeal branch innervates the cricothyroid muscle. its internal laryngeal branch is sensory to the laryngeal mucosa above the vocal folds. the cricothyroid muscle is the only tensor of the vocal fold. this action raises the pitch of the voice. the recurrent laryngeal nerves innervate all other intrinsic muscles of the larynx and supplies sensory fibres to the laryngeal mucosa of the infraglottic space. 18 sometimes called the “inferior laryngeal nerves”
next previous 21a pre-lab slm part 3: the nose and oral cavity

21a the nasal cavity next previous the nasal cavity extends from the nostrils (nares), anteriorly, to the choanae , posteriorly. the choanae are bilaterally-paired openings on either side of the nasal septum, that are continuous with the nasopharynx. each nasal cavity is described as having a floor, formed by the hard palate, a medial wall, formed by the nasal septum, a roof, and a lateral wall. choanae funnel 20

21a the paranasal air sinuses next previous 21 the paranasal air sinuses are cavities in the bones of the skull that open into the nasal cavity. they are lined by the same mucus membrane that lines the nasal cavity, and the mucus produced in these sinuses drains through these openings into the nasal cavities. the paranasal air sinuses are named according to the bone in which they are located. thus, they are the frontal sinus (a), ethmoidal air cells (b), maxillary sinus (c) and sphenoid sinus. the sinuses of the ethmoid bone, the ethmoid air cells, consist of a group of small spaces, much like clusters of soap bubbles, within the lateral masses of the ethmoid bone. note in the lower diagram that they are located lateral to the sphenoethmoidal recess (d) and the superior (e) and middle (f) meatuses. the posterior ethmoid air cells open into the superior meatus.

21a the sphenopalatine foramen next previous the sphenopalatine foramen (b) is, as the name suggests, an opening between the sphenoid and palatine bones (a). it is located posterior to the cut edge of the middle concha. recall that this opening connects the nasal cavity with the pterygopalatine fossa. it is through this opening that branches of the maxillary nerve (c) and artery (d) gain access to the mucosa lining the nasal cavity 22

21a the nerve supply to the nasal cavity next previous the maxillary nerve, v2, passes from the cranial cavity, via the foramen rotundum, into the pterygopalatine fossa. from there, its nasal branches pass through the sphenopalatine foramen into the mucosa of the nasal cavity. the lateral nasal branches (a) of the maxillary nerve (v2) supply much of the lateral wall of the nasal cavity. the nasopalatine branch (b) of the maxillary nerve (v2) crosses the roof of the nose from lateral to medial, from the sphenopalatine foramen to the mucosa of the nasal septum. the distal part of the nasopalatine nerve leaves the anterior part of the septum to pass through the incisive foramen (c) to innervate the anterior portion of the oral surface of the hard palate. thus, most of the nasal cavity is innervated by branches of the maxillary nerve, v2. 23 however, the anterior part of the lateral wall and septum is innervated by branches of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve, v1. (d).

21a the blood supply to the nasal cavity next previous the sphenopalatine artery (a), a branch of the maxillary artery (b) enters the mucosa of the nasal cavity via the sphenopalatine foramen. its lateral nasal branches (c) supply much of the lateral wall, and its septal branches (d) cross the roof of the nose to supply blood to the nasal septum. while most of the nasal mucosa receives blood from branches of the maxillary artery, branches of the ophthalmic artery (e) supply the olfactory part of the nasal mucosa, and branches of the facial artery (f) supply of the mucosa in the anterior part of the nose, and branches of the greater palatine artery (g) ascends via the incisive foramen to contribute to the supply of the anterior nasal septum these vessels anastomose freely within the nasal mucosa. the anastomoses in the info anterior, inferior, nasal septum between branches of the maxillary, facial and ophthalmic arteries are 24 particularly rich, and create a complex called keisselbach’s plexus (h), making this area particularly prone to nosebleeds (epistaxis). this area is commonly referred to as keisselbach’s area or little’s area. the majority of nosebleeds occur in this location.

21a summary: the blood and nerve supply to the nasal cavity next previous the figure on the right is a posterior view of a coronally-sectioned skull, looking outward through the right nasal cavity and piriform aperture. the maxillary nerve, v2, and artery (a) are shown in the pterygopalatine fossa, along with the pterygopalatine ganglion (b). the sphenopalatine artery and maxillary nerve give rise to lateral nasal branches (c). the nasopalatine branch (d) of the maxillary nerve and the septal branches (e) of the sphenopalatine artery cross the roof of the nasal cavity from lateral to medial, from the sphenopalatine foramen to the mucosa of the nasal septum. 25

21a the borders of the oral cavity next previous this schematic focuses on the oral cavity. notice that the oral cavity opens anteriorly at the oral fissure. its roof is formed by the hard palate, its floor is formed by the tongue and associated mucosa, and its lateral walls are formed by the cheeks. the oral cavity ends posteriorly at the oropharyngeal isthmus , which is the narrowing that leads to the oropharynx. the oropharyngeal isthmus is guarded by the soft palate, which, as depicted by the blue arrows in the diagram, is raised in swallowing to isolate the oropharynx from the nasopharynx. this ensures that food proceeds toward the digestive tract, and not upward into the nasal cavities. isthmus the portion of a space or structure where it narrows 26

21a the oral cavity, anterior view next previous the oropharyngeal isthmus is bounded by the soft palate superiorly, two pairs of mucosal folds laterally, and the base of the tongue inferiorly. the anterior member of each pair of mucosal folds is the palatoglossal fold (b) or anterior pillar, created by the underlying palatoglossus muscle. the posterior member of each pair is the palatopharyngeal fold (c) or posterior pillar, created by the palatopharyngeus muscle. between the palatoglossal and palatopharyngeal folds, lies a palatine tonsil (d). these tonsils are largest in children, atrophy with age, and may even have been removed during the lifetime of the cadaver you will study. look in the mirror, open your mouth, and identify your soft palate (e), uvula (f), palatoglossal and palatopharyngeal folds, and if possible, your palatine tonsils. palatopharyngeal related to the palate and the pharynx uvula little grape (l) 27 palatoglossal related to the palate and the tongue; glossus (gr) = tongue

21.3 if you can name it, you can pierce it! previous upper (right) and lower (below) frenulum piercings. 4a 21a the oral vestibule next previous the oral cavity consists of the vestibule and the oral cavity proper. the oral vestibule is the space outside the teeth; it is therefore bounded by the lips and cheeks externally, and the teeth and gums (gingiva) internally. the oral cavity proper is the space contained within the alveolar processes and teeth. again, while looking in the mirror, lift your upper lip and then turn down your lower lip and identify the superior and inferior labial frenula in the midline of each . these are folds of mucous membrane that connect the lip to the gingiva. 28

21a innervation of the floor of the mouth next previous 29 the lingual nerve is a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve, v3. it is responsible for general sensation from that anterior 2/3 of the tongue. the lingual nerve also distributes taste fibres to this region that it receives from the chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve, cn vii in addition to taste fibres, the chorda tympani contributes parasympathetic preganglionic fibres to the lingual nerve. the lingual nerve carries them to the floor of the mouth, where they synapse on the submandibular ganglion. postganglionic fibres are distributed to the submandibular and sublingual glands, and the mucosa of the anterior 2/3 of the tongue and floor of the mouth. the hypoglossal nerve (d), you will recall, is motor to the intrinsic and most extrinsic muscles of the tongue.
next previous 21a pre-lab slm part 4: fascial compartments of the neck

21a fascial compartments of the neck i next previous the deep fascia of the neck is organized into several layers which create compartments that determine the flow of free fluid and the spread of disease and infection. in the diagram, identify the: investing fascia surrounding all structures in the neck prevertebral fascia surrounding the vertebral compartment pretracheal fascia surrounding the visceral compartment carotid sheath surrounding the vascular compartment 31

21a fascial compartments of the neck ii next previous the investing fascia surrounds all structures in the neck. it is attached posteriorly to the superior nuchal line. note in the diagram that it splits to enclose the trapezius, the scm and the infrahyoid muscles. the prevertebral fascia surrounds the vertebral compartment. note in the diagram that it contains the cervical part of the vertebral column, the prevertebral muscles, the deep muscles of the back and the anterior, middle and posterior scalene muscles. nuchal nape of the neck 32 as the roots of the brachial plexus and the subclavian artery emerge from in between the anterior and middle scalene to enter the upper limb, they carry out an extension of this fascial layer which forms the axillary sheath.

21a fascial compartments of the neck iii next previous the pretracheal fascia surrounds the visceral compartment. note in the diagram that contained within this compartment is the esophagus, larynx, trachea, and thyroid gland. more superiorly, it surrounds the pharynx as the buccopharyngeal fascia. the carotid sheath is the layer of fascia surrounding the vascular compartment. note in the diagram that it contains the common carotid artery (and, more superiorly, its internal carotid branch), the internal jugular vein, and the vagus nerve. 33 in the axial mris that follows, outline the vertebral, visceral and vascular compartments. identify the positions in which the vagus nerves, recurrent laryngeal nerves, and phrenic nerves are located.

6.1 radiology: an axial mri of the neck 15a 21a radiology: an axial mri of the neck next previous in the mri of the neck identify the: cervical vertebral body (a) and neural arch (b) esophagus (c) cricoid cartilage (d) thyroid gland (e) internal jugular vein (f) and common carotid artery (g) scm (h), infrahyoid (i) and trapezius muscles (j). 34 click here for the answer ®

6.1 radiology: an axial mri of the neck 15a 21a radiology: an axial mri of the neck next previous in the mri of the neck identify the location of the: investing fascia (a) pretracheal fascia (b) and visceral compartment (c) prevertebral fascia (d) and vertebral compartment (e) carotid sheath (f) and vascular compartment (g) 35 click here for the answer ®
