slidetranscripts.slidetranscript:
The paranasal air sinuses are commonly referred to as the “sinuses”. They are bilaterally-paired, mucous membrane-lined spaces in the cranial bones that open into the nasal cavities. Mucous produced in these spaces drains via these openings into the nasal cavities.

The paranasal air sinuses are named according to the bone in which they are located; these are the frontal sinuses, the ethmoid air cells, the maxillary sinuses, and the sphenoid sinuses, which are described on the next slide.

The ethmoid air cells are a series of honey comb-like spaces within the lateral masses of the ethmoid bone, between the nasal cavity and the orbit. More specifically, they are located lateral to the sphenoethmoid recess, and the superior and middle meatuses.

In the half head sectioned such that it shows the lateral wall of the nasal cavity, identify the sphenoid air sinus. Locate the opening between the sphenoid air sinus and the sphenoethmoidal recess. It is via this opening that mucous drains from the sphenoid sinus into the sphenoethmoidal recess.

Once you have removed the middle and inferior conchae using small scissors, you will identify features of the middle meatus. First, identify the semilunar hiatus, and above it, the ethmoidal bulla. The ethmoidal bulla is a surface feature of the lateral wall of the nasal cavity formed by the middle ethmoid air cells. The middle and anterior ethmoid air cells open into the middle meatus in this region.

The largest of the paranasal air sinuses are the maxillary sinuses. They drain into the nasal cavity via openings roughly at the midpoint of the semilunar hiatus. Locate this opening using a blunt probe, taking care not to create any new openings in the lateral wall of the nasal cavity.

In the inferior meatus, you will find the opening of the nasolacrimal duct, which drains tears from the orbit into the nasal cavity. This is why your nose runs when you cry.

I’ll show you here how to find the opening of the nasolacrimal duct in a skull.

On a skull, identify the opening of the nasolacrimal duct in the medial, inferior aspect of the orbit. Pass a pipe cleaner, gently, through this opening and observe it emerge in the inferior meatus of the nasal cavity.

Posterior to the cut edge of the middle and inferior concha is the perpendicular plate of the palatine bone. In it, posterior to the cut edge of the middle concha is the sphenopalatine foramen. In your specimen, this opening in the perpendicular plate of the palatine bone that is covered over by mucous membrane – using the tip of a scalpel, scrape away the mucous membrane overlying the sphenopalatine foramen and identify it. It is an opening between the pterygopalatine fossa and the nasal cavity. Nerves and blood vessels pass from the pterygopalatine fossa, through the sphenopalatine foramen, into the submucosa underlying the nasal mucosa. These nerves are sensory branches of the maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve and the arteries are branches of the maxillary artery.

In the last lab, you identified the pterygopalatine fossa while studying the prosection of the infratemporal fossa. Click on the red arrow at the bottom of the slide and I’ll explain further how these nerves and blood vessels travel.

The pterygopalatine fossa has been described as junction box. A junction box takes input from one source and distributes it to many destinations.

In last lab, you identified the pterygomaxillary fissure, bordered by the anterior border of the lateral pterygoid plate and the posterior border of the maxillary bone. It opens from the infratemporal fossa into the pterygopalatine fossa. Using the skull provided that has pipe cleaners passed through various foramina, confirm that the pterygopalatine foramen communicates

•anteriorly with the orbit via the inferior orbital fissure

•medially with the nasal cavity via the sphenopalatine foramen

•inferiorly with the oral cavity via the greater and lesser palatine canals, and

•posteriorly with the cranial cavity through the foramen rotundum and pterygoid canal.

•while the canal involved is too small to pass a pipe cleaner through, the pterygopalatine fossa also communicates posteriorly with the pharynx

Let’s start with the blood supply to the nasal cavity: recall from last lab that the maxillary artery passes through the infratemporal fossa and into the pterygopalatine fossa. There it gives rise to the sphenopalatine artery, which passes through the sphenopalatine foramen to supply blood to the mucosa of the lateral wall of the nasal cavity.

Now the nerve supply: the maxillary branch of the trigeminal nerve is a general sensory nerve. It passes out of the cranial cavity via the foramen rotundum, and into the pterygopalatine fossa. There, it gives rise to branches that pass through the sphenopalatine foramen to ramify in the submucosa of the lateral nasal wall.

In addition, it gives rise to general sensory nerves that

•pass through the inferior orbital fissure, into the orbit, and then exit through the inferior orbital foramen as the infraorbital nerve, which supplies general sensation to the skin overlying the maxilla

•pass through the greater and lesser palatine canals to supply general sensation to the palate.

•pass posteriorly to supply general sensation to the nasopharynx

Similar to an earlier slide, these pictures illustrate the lateral and medial walls of the right nasal cavity as if the skull ad be sectioned just to the right of the midline, and then opened like a book.

Look at the specimen demonstrating the lateral wall of the nasal cavity. The lateral nasal branches of the maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve pass through the sphenopalatine foramen to ramify in the mucosa of the lateral wall of the nasal cavity.

Look at the specimen demonstrating the nasal septum, or the medial wall of the nasal cavity. The nasopalatine branch of the maxillary nerve passes through the sphenopalatine foramen, and arches medially across the roof of the nasal cavity, to gain access to the mucosa lining the nasal septum. The terminus of the nasopalatine nerve passes through the incisive foramen to supply touch fibres to the anterior extremity of the hard palate.

In this way, most of the nasal cavity is supplied by branches of the maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve.

An exception is the anterior part of the lateral wall AND septum, which is innervated by the anterior ethmoidal nerves. These arise from the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve.

While this might sound hard to remember, firstly, the names of the nerves are helpful. The LATERAL nasal nerves supply the LATERAL wall of the nasal cavity. The NASO-PALATINE nerve supplies the NASAL SEPTUM and a portion of the HARD PALATE. These all arise from the maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve. Now click on the red arrow at the bottom of the slide and i’ll try to help you make a little more sense of it.

Recall from last lab the innervation of the skin of the face. Firstly, the territory of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve includes the area of skin extending from the bridge of the nose to its tip. The internal surface of the nasal cavity in this region is also ophthalmic nerve territory, being supplied by the anterior ethmoidal nerves. The maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve supplies the skin of the cheek and upper lip, but also the skin of the lateral aspect of the nose. The internal surface of the nasal cavity in this region is also maxillary nerve territory, being supplied by its lateral nasal branches.

The blood vessels follow a pattern very similar to that of the nerves. Recall that the SPHENOPALATINE ARTERY, a branch of the MAXILLARY ARTERY, passes from the pterygopalatine fossa to the nasal cavity by passing through the sphenopalatine foramen.

It gives rise to LATERAL NASAL branches, which supply the LATERAL WALL of the nasal cavity. Its SEPTAL branches cross the roof of the nasal cavity, from lateral to medial, to supply the nasal SEPTUM. Again the names are helpful to learning the distribution.

There are rich anastomoses in the nasal mucosa. It receives blood from the ethmoidal branches of the ophthalmic artery, nasal branches of the facial artery, and ascending branches of the greater palatine artery. This rich anastomosis where four vessels supply the same region of mucosa is called Keisselbach’s plexus. The region is called Keisselbach’s area. This is the most common location of nose bleeds, or epistaxis.

This figure from Grant’s Atlas provides a good summary of the blood and nerve supply to the medial and lateral walls of the nasal cavity. it is of a coronal section through the skull. You are looking outward through the right nasal cavity and piriform aperture.

Here you see the maxillary branch of the trigeminal nerve in the pterygopalatine fossa, along with the pterygopalatine ganglion. The infraorbital nerve is shown passing anteriorly into the orbit, through the inferior orbital fissure.

Here you see the sphenopalatine artery and maxillary nerve giving rise to lateral nasal branches that pass through the sphenopalatine foramen to supply the lateral wall of the nasal cavity.

Here you see the nasopalatine branch of the maxillary nerve and the septal branches of the sphenopalatine artery arching across the roof of the nasal cavity to its medial wall.

keep in mind that this distribution of nerves and arteries is taking place deep to the mucosa lining the nasal cavity.

The paranasal air sinuses are named according to the bone in which they are located; these are the frontal sinuses, the ethmoid air cells, the maxillary sinuses, and the sphenoid sinuses, which are described on the next slide.

In your specimen, this opening in the perpendicular plate of the palatine bone that is covered over by mucous membrane – using the tip of a scalpel, scrape away the mucous membrane overlying the sphenopalatine foramen and identify it. It is an opening between the pterygopalatine fossa and the nasal cavity. In the last lab, you identified the pterygopalatine fossa while studying the prosection of the infratemporal fossa. Click on the red arrow at the bottom of the slide and I’ll explain further how these nerves and blood vessels travel.

The pterygopalatine fossa has been described as junction box. A junction box takes input from one source and distributes it to many destinations.

It opens from the infratemporal fossa into the pterygopalatine fossa. Recall from last lab the innervation of the skin of the face. Firstly, the territory of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve includes the area of skin extending from the bridge of the nose to its tip. The internal surface of the nasal cavity in this region is also ophthalmic nerve territory, being supplied by the anterior ethmoidal nerves. The maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve supplies the skin of the cheek and upper lip, but also the skin of the lateral aspect of the nose. The internal surface of the nasal cavity in this region is also maxillary nerve territory, being supplied by its lateral nasal branches.

The blood vessels follow a pattern very similar to that of the nerves. Recall that the SPHENOPALATINE ARTERY, a branch of the MAXILLARY ARTERY, passes from the pterygopalatine fossa to the nasal cavity by passing through the sphenopalatine foramen.

It gives rise to LATERAL NASAL branches, which supply the LATERAL WALL of the nasal cavity. Its SEPTAL branches cross the roof of the nasal cavity, from lateral to medial, to supply the nasal SEPTUM. Again the names are helpful to learning the distribution.

There are rich anastomoses in the nasal mucosa. It receives blood from the ethmoidal branches of the ophthalmic artery, nasal branches of the facial artery, and ascending branches of the greater palatine artery. This rich anastomosis where four vessels supply the same region of mucosa is called Keisselbach’s plexus. The region is called Keisselbach’s area. This is the most common location of nose bleeds, or epistaxis.

This figure from Grant’s Atlas provides a good summary of the blood and nerve supply to the medial and lateral walls of the nasal cavity. it is of a coronal section through the skull. You are looking outward through the right nasal cavity and piriform aperture.

Here you see the maxillary branch of the trigeminal nerve in the pterygopalatine fossa, along with the pterygopalatine ganglion. The infraorbital nerve is shown passing anteriorly into the orbit, through the inferior orbital fissure.

Here you see the sphenopalatine artery and maxillary nerve giving rise to lateral nasal branches that pass through the sphenopalatine foramen to supply the lateral wall of the nasal cavity.

Here you see the nasopalatine branch of the maxillary nerve and the septal branches of the sphenopalatine artery arching across the roof of the nasal cavity to its medial wall.

keep in mind that this distribution of nerves and arteries is taking place deep to the mucosa lining the nasal cavity.
